content.description:
Weeping Wall is the face on the left side of Misery,to the left of False Perspective.  Both corners are off, as are the good holds way left.   

  A very hard start (unless you have it wired) gives way to easier climbing. Plan on having trust in the frictional properties of quartzite if you want your feet to stick.
content.protection: Standard TR gear--may have been led.

content.description: Considered by many to be one of the harder .10's at the Lake, Wailing Wall may be undergraded at .10c.  Wail up the face to the right of False Perspective, and certainly don't use the great holds behind and to the right of you on Fat Man's Misery and the Pillow.  Steep rock and off-balance climbing makes this climb a memorable one.
The crux is at the bottom of the route.  It is the at the first 15 feet.  After that the route is around 5.0.  It is a fun route to practice placing gear.
content.protection: The route takes pro very well.  The bottom needs big stuff, but there is pro everywhere.
content.location: The route is to the left of weeping wall.  It is the large crack that move up to the broken stuff.

content.description: This climb starts in the 5.2 block access route on the right side of the pillow block, but climbs slightly right into the chimney between routes 12 and 13

Fun "adventure" climb - start deep in the dark cave that holds Fat Man's Misery and chimney to the opening at the top, maybe about 20 feet up. Emerge on the outside and build an anchor or continue up another 10 feet or so.
content.protection: Light rack with mostly sub-1" gear. You can get a stopper or small cam in a finger crack in the cave (a headlamp might actually be useful). Or solo.
content.location: Starts inside the obvious cave; climbs out through a hole in the top.

content.description: This formation varies in difficulty, both in the climbing and the ability to protect.  South edge (grabbing the edge is off) is a balancy slab with many high steps, as you move north the climbing gets easier and the pro gets better.  Either route comes back to the left (south) to pass through the small roof at the top.  On lead, the climber is looking at a fall onto the slab until well past the roof and into the finish moves.  While these moves are easy, the fall potential should not be taken lightly....
content.protection: Small nuts (#3-5) brassies, small cams (.3 & .4) camalot, tricams (pink to 1st blue), #3.5 camalot up high, maybe a few medium nuts higher, long runners will help with rope drag, or use two ropes to shorten potential falls.

content.description: It's the edge of the pillow, duh. Start near (not on) upward protruding rock that looks very unappealing in the case of a fall. Use the arete to gain the first horizontal and place a good cam. From here you have options... and you have to find those options. Place marginal gear along the way and try not to fall. Finish in cool finger crack at the top to a pleasant mantle finish. A true sportsman wouldn't bail into the chimney of Fat Man's Misery...
content.protection: Standard Rack. Take a big cam for the top.
content.location: The south facing edge of The Pillow. Use the arete and the obvious horizontals.

content.description: This route climbs the edges and thin crack up the right side of the pillow block

If you start this climb as a skinny toddler and climb very, very slowly with really long rests, you could potentially climb on nice jams all the way up.

 Unnamed 5.4, route 13, in Swartling & Mayer's 3rd edition.
content.protection: Should be able to sew this up with a standard rack.
content.location: Look for a thin crack on the face to the right of the cave. Follow this up a series of ledges - the crack widens a little at each level.

content.description:
This climb shares the start of route 14 from a "Climbers Guide to Devils Lake" up to the large tree on the ledge.  From there route 14 goes to the right up the arete and hand size crack on the right side of the crack. 

  In the Way goes back into the chimney behind the tree, and then traverses out into the hanging offwidth/chimney
content.protection: standard rack, something big for the hanging chimney

content.description: Fat Man's Misery climbs inside the "cave" at Misery Rock between Wailing Wall and Pillow's Edge. Use the west face at first and then onto solid corners of "the pillow" to get into a body sized chimney. Don't go too far into the chimney otherwise you'll feel the route's namesake. Finishes on top of "the pillow."
content.protection: None until you are ready to pull out of the chimney. Â Standard rack from there.

content.description:
Is the false perspective from the climber on the route or from those who say it looks too easy?  Start in an inside corner on the center of the face to the left of the Pillow. Climb a crack through a small sloping roof to the top.   

  This climb is a bit harder than it looks, but takes gear very well for a lead.
#8 in Sven's. Follow good holds left of center on The Pillow. Escape right at the overhang. A fun little warm up climb.
content.location: Between the Pillow and the Pillow Right Side.Â

pathTokens: West Bluff 02 - Misery Rocks & The Pantry

content.description:
Misery is so named for the feeling one gets when attempting to climb here on the weekend.  Ease of access and many good beginner climbs (along with some pretty hard routes) makes this a very popular area for groups.  

  The climbs in this area have been blessed with a great, flat hang out area at the bottom.  Most routes have been led, but for obvious reasons, some are more popular than others.  The Pillow, an aptly named rock slab leaning against the right side of Misery Rocks, offers great slab routes on its front side and shelter from the rain on the other side.
